pullRequest.title: Replace Nashorn with GraalVM JS engine in UDF.
pullRequest.bodyText:
Summary of the changes / Why this improves CrateDB
This changes replaces the Nashorn with GraalVM JavaScript
engine, such as Nashorn is scheduled for removal in the
future JDK version, see https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/335.
Please note that we do  not use the GraalVM JIT compiler as the
optimizing compile of the GraalVM JavaScript code, but instead
the GraalVM JavaScript engine is used to compile and execute
JavaScript code.
Checklist

 User relevant changes are recorded in CHANGES.txt
 Touched code is covered by tests
 Documentation has been updated if necessary
 CLA is signed
 This does not contain breaking changes, or if it does:

It is released within a major release
It is recorded in CHANGES.txt
It was marked as deprecated in an earlier release if possible
You've thought about the consequences and other components are adapted
(E.g. AdminUI)

nodes.bodyText: This and resolvePolyglotFunctionValue can be moved to the udf package of the sql module once we add support for more languages.

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            ``CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION`` will either create a new function, or replace
          
          
            
            ``CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION`` will either create a new function or replace
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -37,12 +37,13 @@ These functions can be created like so::
     +--------------------------------+
     SELECT 1 row in set (... sec)
 
-``OR REPLACE`` can be used to replace an existing function::
+``CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION`` will either create a new function, or replace

nodes.bodyText:
this could be simplified with a little rewording. for instance:
"It is possible to use named function arguments in the function signature. For example, the calculate_distance function signature has two geo_point arguments named start and end:"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -59,17 +60,18 @@ These functions can be created like so::
     +---------------+
     SELECT 1 row in set (... sec)
 
-Arguments can be named in the function definition.
-
-For example, if you wanted two ``geo_point`` arguments named ``start_point``
-and ``end_point``, you would do it like this::
-
-    cr> CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION calculate_distance(start_point geo_point, end_point geo_point)
-    ...  RETURNS real
-    ...  LANGUAGE JAVASCRIPT
-    ...  AS 'function calculate_distance(start_point, end_point){
-    ...        return Math.sqrt( Math.pow(end_point[0] - start_point[0], 2), Math.pow(end_point[1] - start_point[1], 2));
-    ...      }';
+It is possible to use named function arguments in the function signature. For
+example, the ``calculate_distance`` function signature has two arguments of
+the ``geo_point`` data type that are named as ``start`` and ``end``::

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change

 Supported types
 ===============
 
-The argument types, and the return type of the function can be any of the
-CrateDB supported :ref:`data-types`. Data types of values passed into a
-function must strictly correspond to its argument data types.
+Arguments, and return data types of the function can be any of the CrateDB

nodes.bodyText:
the first sentence of this para can be simplified a little. and the second sentence can be made a little more precise. for example:
"Function arguments and return values can be any supported :ref:data-types. The values passed into a function must strictly correspond to the specified argument data types."
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -105,9 +105,9 @@ You can explicitly assign a schema like this::
 Supported types
 ===============
 
-The argument types, and the return type of the function can be any of the
-CrateDB supported :ref:`data-types`. Data types of values passed into a
-function must strictly correspond to its argument data types.
+Arguments and return data types of the function can be any of the CrateDB
+supported :ref:`data-types`. Data types of values passed into the function
+must strictly correspond to its argument data types.

nodes.bodyText:
"VM" should be expanded the first time it is used in a document, with the expanded version put into italics, like this:

Virtual Machines (VMs)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -197,31 +197,48 @@ Optionally, you can provide a schema::
 Supported languages
 ===================
 
-CrateDB currently only supports the UDF language ``javascript``.
+CrateDB currently only supports the ``JavaScript`` user-defined functions.
 
 .. _udf_lang_js:
 
 JavaScript
 ----------
 
-The UDF language ``javascript`` supports the `ECMAScript 5.1`_ standard.
+The user defined function JavaScript is compatible with the `ECMAScript 2019`_
+specification.
 
 .. NOTE::
 
    The JavaScript language is an :ref:`enterprise feature
    <enterprise-features>`.
 
-CrateDB uses the Java built-in JavaScript engine Nashorn_ to interpret and
-execute functions written in JavaScript. The engine is initialized using the
-``--no-java`` option which basically restricts all access to Java APIs from
-within the JavaScript context. CrateDB's engine also does not allow
-non-standard syntax extensions (``--no-syntax-extensions``).
+CrateDB uses the `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine as a JavaScript (ECMAScript)
+language execution runtime. The `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine is a Java
+application that works on the stock Java VMs. The interoperability between

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            (guest language) is guaranteed thtough the GraalVM `GraalVM Polyglot API`_.
          
          
            
            (guest language) is guaranteed by the GraalVM `GraalVM Polyglot API`_.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -197,31 +197,48 @@ Optionally, you can provide a schema::
 Supported languages
 ===================
 
-CrateDB currently only supports the UDF language ``javascript``.
+CrateDB currently only supports the ``JavaScript`` user-defined functions.
 
 .. _udf_lang_js:
 
 JavaScript
 ----------
 
-The UDF language ``javascript`` supports the `ECMAScript 5.1`_ standard.
+The user defined function JavaScript is compatible with the `ECMAScript 2019`_
+specification.
 
 .. NOTE::
 
    The JavaScript language is an :ref:`enterprise feature
    <enterprise-features>`.
 
-CrateDB uses the Java built-in JavaScript engine Nashorn_ to interpret and
-execute functions written in JavaScript. The engine is initialized using the
-``--no-java`` option which basically restricts all access to Java APIs from
-within the JavaScript context. CrateDB's engine also does not allow
-non-standard syntax extensions (``--no-syntax-extensions``).
+CrateDB uses the `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine as a JavaScript (ECMAScript)
+language execution runtime. The `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine is a Java
+application that works on the stock Java VMs. The interoperability between
+Java code (host language) and JavaScript user-defined functions
+(guest language) is guaranteed thtough the GraalVM `GraalVM Polyglot API`_.

nodes.bodyText:
how about this:

Please note: CrateDB does not use the GraalVM JIT compiler. However, the stock host Java VM JIT compilers_ can JIT-compile, optimize, and execute the GraalVM JavaScript codebase to a certain extent.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -197,31 +197,48 @@ Optionally, you can provide a schema::
 Supported languages
 ===================
 
-CrateDB currently only supports the UDF language ``javascript``.
+CrateDB currently only supports the ``JavaScript`` user-defined functions.
 
 .. _udf_lang_js:
 
 JavaScript
 ----------
 
-The UDF language ``javascript`` supports the `ECMAScript 5.1`_ standard.
+The user defined function JavaScript is compatible with the `ECMAScript 2019`_
+specification.
 
 .. NOTE::
 
    The JavaScript language is an :ref:`enterprise feature
    <enterprise-features>`.
 
-CrateDB uses the Java built-in JavaScript engine Nashorn_ to interpret and
-execute functions written in JavaScript. The engine is initialized using the
-``--no-java`` option which basically restricts all access to Java APIs from
-within the JavaScript context. CrateDB's engine also does not allow
-non-standard syntax extensions (``--no-syntax-extensions``).
+CrateDB uses the `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine as a JavaScript (ECMAScript)
+language execution runtime. The `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine is a Java
+application that works on the stock Java VMs. The interoperability between
+Java code (host language) and JavaScript user-defined functions
+(guest language) is guaranteed thtough the GraalVM `GraalVM Polyglot API`_.
+
+Please note that CrateDB does not use the GraalVM JIT compiler as the
+optimizing compile of the GraalVM JavaScript code as one might expect while
+seeing usage of the GraalVM. The `stock host Java VM JIT compilers`_ still can
+JIT-compile, execute and optimize the GraalVM JavaScript codebase to certain
+extend.

 Supported languages
 ===================
 
-CrateDB currently only supports the UDF language ``javascript``.
+CrateDB currently only supports the ``JavaScript`` user-defined functions.
 
 .. _udf_lang_js:
 
 JavaScript
 ----------
 
-The UDF language ``javascript`` supports the `ECMAScript 5.1`_ standard.
+The user defined function JavaScript is compatible with the `ECMAScript 2019`_
+specification.
 
 .. NOTE::
 
    The JavaScript language is an :ref:`enterprise feature
    <enterprise-features>`.
 
-CrateDB uses the Java built-in JavaScript engine Nashorn_ to interpret and
-execute functions written in JavaScript. The engine is initialized using the
-``--no-java`` option which basically restricts all access to Java APIs from

+CrateDB uses the `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine as a JavaScript (ECMAScript)
+language execution runtime. The `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine is a Java
+application that works on the stock Java VMs. The interoperability between
+Java code (host language) and JavaScript user-defined functions
+(guest language) is guaranteed thtough the GraalVM `GraalVM Polyglot API`_.
+
+Please note that CrateDB does not use the GraalVM JIT compiler as the
+optimizing compile of the GraalVM JavaScript code as one might expect while
+seeing usage of the GraalVM. The `stock host Java VM JIT compilers`_ still can
+JIT-compile, execute and optimize the GraalVM JavaScript codebase to certain
+extend.
+
+The execution context for guest JavaScript language code is created with
+restricted privileges, to allow for the execution of less trusted guest

nodes.bodyText:
how about:

The execution context for guest JavaScript is created with restricted privileges to allow for the safe execution of less trusted guest language code. The guest language application context for each user-defined function is created with default access modifiers, so any access to managed resources is denied. The only exception is the host language interoperability configuration which explicitly allows access to Java lists and arrays. Please refer to GraalVM Security Guide_ for more detailed information.

this reads a little clearer to me. but have I preserved the correct meaning with my edit?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -197,31 +197,48 @@ Optionally, you can provide a schema::
 Supported languages
 ===================
 
-CrateDB currently only supports the UDF language ``javascript``.
+CrateDB currently only supports the ``JavaScript`` user-defined functions.
 
 .. _udf_lang_js:
 
 JavaScript
 ----------
 
-The UDF language ``javascript`` supports the `ECMAScript 5.1`_ standard.
+The user defined function JavaScript is compatible with the `ECMAScript 2019`_
+specification.
 
 .. NOTE::
 
    The JavaScript language is an :ref:`enterprise feature
    <enterprise-features>`.
 
-CrateDB uses the Java built-in JavaScript engine Nashorn_ to interpret and
-execute functions written in JavaScript. The engine is initialized using the
-``--no-java`` option which basically restricts all access to Java APIs from
-within the JavaScript context. CrateDB's engine also does not allow
-non-standard syntax extensions (``--no-syntax-extensions``).
+CrateDB uses the `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine as a JavaScript (ECMAScript)
+language execution runtime. The `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine is a Java
+application that works on the stock Java VMs. The interoperability between
+Java code (host language) and JavaScript user-defined functions
+(guest language) is guaranteed thtough the GraalVM `GraalVM Polyglot API`_.
+
+Please note that CrateDB does not use the GraalVM JIT compiler as the
+optimizing compile of the GraalVM JavaScript code as one might expect while
+seeing usage of the GraalVM. The `stock host Java VM JIT compilers`_ still can
+JIT-compile, execute and optimize the GraalVM JavaScript codebase to certain
+extend.
+
+The execution context for guest JavaScript language code is created with
+restricted privileges to allow for the execution of less trusted guest
+language code. The guest language application context for each user-defined
+function, that controls which resources of the host language can be accessed,
+is created with default access modifiers meaning that the access to all
+managed resources is denied. The exception is only the host language
+interoperability configuration that explicitly allows the access to Java lists
+and arrays. Please refer to `GraalVM Security Guide`_ for more detailed
+information.

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            (e.g. ``window``, ``console`` and so on) are are not available.
          
          
            
            (e.g. ``window``, ``console``, and so on) are not available.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -197,31 +197,48 @@ Optionally, you can provide a schema::
 Supported languages
 ===================
 
-CrateDB currently only supports the UDF language ``javascript``.
+CrateDB currently only supports the ``JavaScript`` user-defined functions.
 
 .. _udf_lang_js:
 
 JavaScript
 ----------
 
-The UDF language ``javascript`` supports the `ECMAScript 5.1`_ standard.
+The user defined function JavaScript is compatible with the `ECMAScript 2019`_
+specification.
 
 .. NOTE::
 
    The JavaScript language is an :ref:`enterprise feature
    <enterprise-features>`.
 
-CrateDB uses the Java built-in JavaScript engine Nashorn_ to interpret and
-execute functions written in JavaScript. The engine is initialized using the
-``--no-java`` option which basically restricts all access to Java APIs from
-within the JavaScript context. CrateDB's engine also does not allow
-non-standard syntax extensions (``--no-syntax-extensions``).
+CrateDB uses the `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine as a JavaScript (ECMAScript)
+language execution runtime. The `GraalVM JavaScript`_ engine is a Java
+application that works on the stock Java VMs. The interoperability between
+Java code (host language) and JavaScript user-defined functions
+(guest language) is guaranteed thtough the GraalVM `GraalVM Polyglot API`_.
+
+Please note that CrateDB does not use the GraalVM JIT compiler as the
+optimizing compile of the GraalVM JavaScript code as one might expect while
+seeing usage of the GraalVM. The `stock host Java VM JIT compilers`_ still can
+JIT-compile, execute and optimize the GraalVM JavaScript codebase to certain
+extend.
+
+The execution context for guest JavaScript language code is created with
+restricted privileges to allow for the execution of less trusted guest
+language code. The guest language application context for each user-defined
+function, that controls which resources of the host language can be accessed,
+is created with default access modifiers meaning that the access to all
+managed resources is denied. The exception is only the host language
+interoperability configuration that explicitly allows the access to Java lists
+and arrays. Please refer to `GraalVM Security Guide`_ for more detailed
+information.
 
 **This, however, does not mean that JavaScript is securely sandboxed.**
 
-Also, even though Nashorn runs ECMA-complient JavaScript, objects that are
-normally accessible with a web browser (e.g. ``window``, ``console`` and so on)
-are are not available.
+Also, even though user-defined functions implemented with ECMA-compliant
+JavaScript, objects that are normally accessible with a web browser
+(e.g. ``window``, ``console`` and so on) are are not available.

nodes.bodyText:
how about:

Replaced the Nashorn JavaScript engine with GraalVM for JavaScript
:ref:user-defined functions <sql_administration_udf>. This change improves the performance of the JavaScript user-defined functions and upgrades ECMAScript support from 5.1 to 10.0.

(slightly reworded first line and last line)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -65,6 +65,12 @@ None
 Changes
 =======
 
+- Replaced the ``Nashorn`` by ``GraalVM`` JavaScript engine in the JavaScript
+  :ref:`user-defined functions <sql_administration_udf>` implementation.
+  This change improves the performance of the JavaScript user-defined
+  functions and upgrades the ``ECMAScript`` specification version from ``5.1``
+  to ``10.0``.

nodes.bodyText: Would the old definition still work, or do users need to update their function definitions?

afterCommit.message:
Replace Nashorn with GraalVM JS engine in UDF.

This changes replaces the Nashorn with GraalVM JavaScript
engine, such as Nashorn is scheduled for removal in the
future JDK version, see https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/335.

Please note that we do  not use the GraalVM JIT compiler as the
optimizing compile of the GraalVM JavaScript code, but instead
the GraalVM JavaScript engine is used to compile and execute
JavaScript code.

commit.message:
Replace Nashorn with GraalVM JS engine in UDF.

This changes replaces the Nashorn with GraalVM JavaScript
engine, such as Nashorn is scheduled for removal in the
future JDK version, see https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/335.

Please note that we do  not use the GraalVM JIT compiler as the
optimizing compile of the GraalVM JavaScript code, but instead
the GraalVM JavaScript engine is used to compile and execute
JavaScript code.

This changes replaces the Nashorn with GraalVM JavaScript
engine, such as Nashorn is scheduled for removal in the
future JDK version, see https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/335.
